news.title: Triple murder suspect hospitalised
news.content:
Walter Nyamukondiwa

Mashonaland West Bureau Chief

Triple murder suspect Trymore Tore (37) who was arrested on Sunday afternoon following a joint police and community search has been admitted at Karoi District Hospital with multiple stab wounds.

Tore stabbed himself with an okapi knife four times on the chest and twice on the neck after realising that community members and the police were closing in on him.

Investigations had led the police to a house in Chikangwe Township, Karoi, but Tore managed to escape.

He retreated to his rural home where villagers and the police combed the area for two days.

On February 23 at around 5.45 pm, villagers spotted Tore hiding in a bush about a kilometre from his homestead.

This led to his apprehension by villagers and subsequent arrest by the police.

Tore was initially taken to Chitindiva Clinic where he was treated and admitted before being transferred to Karoi District Hospital.

He is being held under armed police guard.
news.description: Triple murder suspect Trymore Tore (37) who was arrested on Sunday afternoon following a joint police and community search has been admitted at Karoi District Hospital with multiple stab wounds.

news.title: Mbare cops demand money from motorists passing through police station’s gate
news.content:
Prosper Dembedza

Herald Correspondent

Two police officers who are stationed at Mbare Police Station have been convicted of criminal abuse of office after they were found guilty of charging US$1 to motorists passing through the stations gate.

Naume Dube (31) and Victoria Shonhiwa (36) were remanded in custody to Tuesday for sentencing.

The State, led by Ms Dzidzai Josiah, proved that on March 18 last year, the two cops were deployed at Mbare Police Stations main gate for security reasons.

On the same day, officers from internal investigations received a tip off from members of the public that the duo was demanding US$1 from every motorist driving through the gate.

A team of internal police officers carried out surveillance and saw the duo taking the money.

Court documents state that Shonhiwa received the money and gave it to Dube for safekeeping.

The internal officers immediately pounced on the duo and recovered US$120 after searching them.

The two cops were taken to the Police Internal Investigations Section and were later handed over to the Police Anti-Corruption Unit.

news.title: Dams replenished as water levels surge
news.content:
Ivan Zhakata

Herald Correspondent

Major dams across the country are experiencing a significant rise in water levels, with some reaching full capacity, according to the latest statistics released by the Zimbabwe National Water Authority (Zinwa).

The data paints a promising picture of improved water security.

Lake Mutirikwi and Silalabuhwa Dams have hit 100 percent capacity, indicating a strong recovery after months of fluctuating levels.

Other major dams showing notable increases include Manyuchi whish is at 99,5 percent and Tugwi-Mukosi (96 percent), which is a boost in water reserves for both agricultural and domestic use.however, other dams remain at critically low levels.

Inyankuni Dam is at 9,8 percent while Lower Ncema is among the lowest at 7 percent, thereby raising concerns over water supply in their respective regions.

Upper Ncema (35,2 percent), Mzingwane (33,3 percent), and Mazowe (32,8 percent) also remain below optimal levels, which necessitates continued monitoring and conservation efforts.

Zhovhe (92,6 percent), Masembura (93,1 percent), and Arcadia (82,6 percent) are among the dams that have recorded substantial water retention, while urban supply dams such as Chivero (73,2 percent) and Upper Insiza (75,4 percent) indicate stable conditions for major cities, including Harare and Bulawayo.

The latest dam level statistics reflect a significant improvement from the dry spells that previously threatened agricultural productivity and water supply.

However, authorities remain on high alert for regions with persistently low levels, where water rationing may still be necessary.

Experts remain hopeful that more dams will reach full capacity, ensuring a stable water supply for households, irrigation and hydropower generation in the months ahead.
news.description: Major dams across the country are experiencing a significant rise in water levels, with some reaching full capacity, according to the latest statistics released by the Zimbabwe National Water Authority (Zinwa).

news.title: Re-engagement and engagement helps boost investor confidence: President
news.content:
Thupeyo Muleya

Beitbridge Bureau

President Mnangagwa has said the re-engagement and engagement of old and new strategic partners has helped boost investor confidence in Zimbabwe.

He said more players are now taking up opportunities in the country, especially in the mining and energy sectors.The President said the move said will greatly contribute to Zimbabwes economic development.

President Mnangagwa made these remarks while officiating at the groundbreaking ceremony at Palm River Energy Industrial Park in Beitbridge today (Monday).

Our re-engagement and engagement initiative as the Second Republic is paying dividends, he said.

We commend Xintai Resources for coming forward to invest in the mining and energy sector through the setting up of this industrial park whose first phase is almost complete.

The project is being done in five phases over 12 years.

It is expected to have a coking plant, thermal power station, ferrochrome processing plant, and a carbon and steel plant.

news.title: Zimpapers Tobacco Expo slated for Rusape
news.content:
Ray Bande

Senior Reporter

Zimpapers Mutare (The Manica Post and Diamond FM) will host its inaugural Manicaland Tobacco Expo in Rusape early next month.

The event, which coincides with the launch of the 2025 tobacco marketing season, seeks to explore business opportunities and facilitate networking among tobacco industry stakeholders, including farmers, service providers, merchants and buyers.

The expo provides a rare platform for tobacco stakeholders to come under one roof to address the challenges that have plagued the industry in previous years, hindering productivity and profitability.

The Manica Post Finance and Admin Officer, Mr Advance Khumalo said: We feel there is a yawning gap and hunger for an understanding of the complexities in the tobacco industry, hence this idea to host the Tobacco Expo.

We will bring together all the stakeholders in the tobacco value chain  from growers, service providers, policy regulators, buyers to merchants  during the three-day event.

Mr Khumalo said the door is also open for exhibitors in the tobacco and related industries.

We will have room for exhibitors to showcase their products and services during this event. This could be service providers in the tobacco industry or any of those whose services and products relate to the industry, said Mr Khumalo.

The Tobacco Industry and Marketing Board (TIMB) last week announced that the 2025 tobacco marketing season commences on March 5 for auction floors and March 6 for contract sales.

Zimbabwe is expecting 300 million kg of tobacco this season after farmers increased the area under tobacco to 84 661 hectares, surpassing last years 82 392 hectares.

Tobacco is the countrys second-largest foreign currency earner after gold, with about 98 percent of the locally produced crop exported in semi-processed form, amid growing calls for value addition.

There has been high demand for the cash crop in China, and funding from both Government and private tobacco companies has boosted output.
news.description: Zimpapers Mutare (The Manica Post and Diamond FM) will host its inaugural Manicaland Tobacco Expo in Rusape early next month.

news.title: President Mnangagwa launches Beitbridge’s US$3.6 billion industrial park
news.content:
Nqobile Bhebhe in Beitbridge

President Mnangagwa has officiated at the groundbreaking and plaque unveiling ceremony of the US$3.6 billion Palm River Energy Metallurgical Special Economic Zone project in Beitbridge.

The landmark project, which shows growing investor confidence in the Second Republic, has the potential to significantly transform the economy of the Matabeleland region and the country at large.

Palm River is a multi-faceted project that will encompass mining, power generation, coke production, and steel manufacturing.

With its focus on energy, mining, and value addition, the project has the potential to transform the Matabeleland region into a hub of industrial activity and economic growth.

The President and his delegation toured the industrial park.

Vice President Dr Constantino Chiwenga, Vice President Kembo Mohadi, the Minister of State for Matabeleland South Provincial Affairs and Devolution Dr Evelyn Ndlovu, Finance, Economic Development and Investment Promotion Minister Professor

Mthuli Ncube, Mines and Mining Development Minister Winston Chitando and Chinese embassy officials were part of the delegation.

Several players in the mining sector and Beitbridge community leaders were also present.

The project, which is expected to play a crucial role in strengthening Zimbabwes mining and energy sectors, was set up following discussions between the companys chairman and President Mnangagwa.

It will ultimately produce stainless steel, and is being implemented in phases.

The project covers an area of 5,163 hectares and will be constructed in five phases over 12 years. The first phase of construction will be done in two years, with a total investment of US$237 million.

In 2018, President Mnangagwa declared Beitbridge a Special Economic Zone as part of the Second Republics broader strategy to attract investment.

The SEZ model aims to enhance foreign direct investment, improve local business competitiveness, and drive economic growth.

news.title: Gokwe South gets fire tender
news.content:
Jerry Chifamba

In another milestone achieved under devolution, the Government has commissioned a fire tender for Gokwe South District.

The fire tender is part of the 133 units acquired from Belarus to enhance service delivery and community safety across Zimbabwe.

Speaking at the commissioning ceremony, Midlands Provincial Affairs and Devolution Minister Owen Ncube commended the Second Republic for its commitment to inclusive development.

As we approach the conclusion of NDS1 and the dawn of NDS2 in 2026, I wish to applaud the Second Republic for transforming the livelihoods of communities through bold, robust, and transformative programmes, he said.

The devolution funds have empowered local authorities to improve service delivery, modernise infrastructure, and implement life-changing projects.
news.description: In another milestone achieved under devolution, the Government has commissioned a fire tender for Gokwe South District.

news.title: President in Beitbridge for the groundbreaking of a US$3,6bn industrial park
news.content:
Thupeyo Muleya

Beitbridge Bureau

President Mnangagwa has arrived in Beitbridge for a groundbreaking ceremony of the Palm River Energy and Metallurgical Special Economic Zone.

Government, in collaboration with a Chinese mining company, is developing a US$3,6 billion energy industrial park in the border town.

The President is accompanied by Vice Presidents Constantino Chiwenga and Kembo Mohadi, Matabeleland South Minister of State Dr Evelyn Ndlovu; Finance, Economic Development, and Investment Promotion Minister, Professor Mthuli Ncube; Mines and Mining Development Minister Winston Chitando and other senior Government officials.

Representatives from the Chinese embassy and mining experts are also present.

The project, which is 20km west of Beitbridge town, seeks to produce stainless steel. The energy and steelworks initiative has already employed 400 local workers in its first year, with the expectation that it will ultimately employ over 2 000 people once it becomes fully operational.

This follows discussions between the chairman of Palm River Energy, Mr Xong Xi Dong, and President Mnangagwa.

The project will cover 5 100 hectares within a Special Economic Zone and is expected to make substantial contributions to Zimbabwes mining and energy sectors.

Its first phase is being carried out through a joint venture between the Government, Xintai Resources and Tuli Coal.

After the groundbreaking ceremony, the President is expected to tour the park which comprises a coking plant that will have an annual capacity of producing one million tonnes of coke, a ferrochrome smelting plant that will produce 100 000 tonnes of high-carbon ferrochrome, and a 1 200MW coal-fired thermal power plant.

Any surplus electricity will be fed onto the national grid, while the ferrochrome plant will facilitate the production of stainless steel and castings.

Coal supply to the project will be obtained from Tuli Coal Mine.
news.description: President Mnangagwa has arrived in Beitbridge for a groundbreaking ceremony of the Palm River Energy and Metallurgical Special Economic Zone.

news.title: Major boost for Chipinge’s health sector
news.content:
Online Reporter

Mount Selinda and Checheches St Peters Hospitals recently acquired state-of-the-art X-ray machines, thereby significantly improving their diagnostic capabilities.

This will enhance the quality of health services provided to Chipinge community members who were previously forced to travel to Victoria Chitepo Provincial Hospital in Mutare for such services.

Dr Ozzimmo Matekenya, the Chipinge District Medical Officer, expressed his excitement and invited members of the public to take full advantage of the crucial health services now offered at these two public institutions.
